Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT30-COX 
    

 UPDATE      UPDATE
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR WEDNESDAY, Aug. 30, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Eds. Adds: RUSSIA-SPY, HATECRIME, ONEFLA, ALASKA-TRAVEL,
FBN-DILLON, GAPOWER-RACISM, MEXICO-ABORTION ;

   deletes: FANCY-FOOD

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-ABORTION _ MEXICO CITY _ The governor of Mexico's
Guanajuato state on Tuesday vetoed a controversial new state law
that would have mandated jail time for rape victims who get
abortions. Abortion, which is mostly illegal in Mexico, has been a
sensitive topic lately as the right and left fight over whether to
further restrict or liberalize abortion rights. The governor, who
belongs to same conservative party that pushed the new law in the
Guanajuato legislature, backed up his decision with an opinion poll
of attitudes in his state that he recently commissioned. (Ferriss,
Cox News Service).

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   Expected to move by 6:30 p.m. (ET) on the NYT Wire.

   RUSSIA-SPY _ MOSCOW _ Wasted and weary after being held for five
months in a Russian jail on charges of espionage, American
businessman Edmond Pope has little hope of going free or receiving
a fair trial, relatives and U.S. officials said Tuesday. Pope's
wife, Cheri, who was allowed a two-hour visit with him in the
notorious Lefortovo prison on Tuesday, reiterated her husband's
innocence. She said his health has deteriorated so much that she is
afraid Pope, 54, who has a rare form of bone cancer, will die if
not released soon. (Coker, Cox News Service)

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   MOVED on the NYT Wire in both International and Washington
categories..

   MEXICO-LALOBA _ CHIMALHUACAN, Mexico _ ``La Loba,'' the
She-Wolf, is the intimidating nickname of Guadalupe Buendia, a
woman said to have amassed wealth and power in this vast slum of
1.2 million people next to Mexico City. Buendia was a local fixture
of Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI -
which tolerated her abuses. Through a network of nepotism, she kept
herself and her family in charge here for years. But they did
little to improve conditions; garbage is picked up by donkeys and
carts, running water and toilets are luxuries. One woman blames her
for a barrage of bullets fired through her door one recent night.
La Loba is now under arrest, charged with organizing a murderous
attack on a political rival who had defeated her machine in a
recent election. The story of how she controlled people's lives
here reflects a political culture Mexico is struggling to put
behind it. (Ferris, Cox News Service) WITH PHOTOS.

   With information for locator map.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   Moved on the NYT Wire.

   TURNER _ Ted Turner, who once said that Christianity was ``for
losers,'' gives the keynote address at the Millenium World Peace
Summit at the United Nations. The summit of 1,000 religious leaders
received funding from Turner's U.N. Foundation. (Melvin, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   NATIONAL

   SAT-SCORES _ WASHINGTON _ Average scores reached a 30-year high
in math and stayed steady on the verbal portion of SAT college
admission tests nationally, even though the large group of students
taking the test included a higher proportion than ever of people
who usually score slightly lower _ women, non-whites, foreign-born
students and those whose parents didn't go to college. State-level
ledes will be provided for Cox states, unless (like Atlanta) you
notify us you're doing your own locally. With data for textbox or
graphic. (Mollison, Cox News Service)

   HATECRIME _ WEST PALM BEACH _ Law enforcement and prosecutors
across the country would get more money to investigate and put
people away for hate crimes under federal legislation proposed by
Florida Congressmen Bill McCollum and Mark Foley. The pair plans to
use Palm Beach County's hate crime program as a model for the
nation. (Crowley, Palm Beach Post)

   RAMSEYS _ The Ramseys are back for another day of questioning by
Boulder police at attorney Lin Wood's Atlanta office. Expected to
wrap up today. We'll talk to legal experts about each sides'
potential strategies for these sessions. (Schneider, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTO

   ONEFLA _ TALLAHASSEE _The day after classes began at most
schools in the State University System, the governor and
educational leaders say more minorities have enrolled than last
year. But while there are nearly 1,200 more blacks, Asians and
Latinos on the 10 public university campuses, the actual makeup of
the total university population remains about the same. (Palm Beach
Post)

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   NEWT-TV _ A preview/review of the PBS special on the Fall of
Newt Gingrich, a 90-minute special narrated by Blair Brown that
tracks Newt's exploits from the '98 elections through his
retirement. (Jubera, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   Also moving in Entertainment category (e).

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ The inability of Republican presidential
candidate George W. Bush to animate the electorate with his plans
for whopping tax cuts suggests we're not all that angry about how
much we're paying in taxes, despite years of hysterical tutoring by
talk-radio alarmists, anarchy-lite libertarians, supply-siders and,
of course, Republicans. (Teepen, Cox News Service.) MOVED.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ I admit to some manner of exhilaration at Al
Gore's landmark decision to have Joe Lieberman as his running mate.
Nevertheless, I have worried about Lieberman since his
Bible-quoting first appearance alongside Gore in Nashville earlier
this month. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ SANDWICH, Mass. _ Cool, drizzly days here on
Cape Cod drive visitors off the beaches and into the tiny villages
situated up and down the coast line of this intriguing arm of land
so boldly flexing its muscle out into the Atlantic. Like locusts,
they swarm into shopping malls, picking them clean of must-have
items like genuine resin replicas of island lighthouses (made in
Taiwan), or sea shells (shipped in from Florida). (Schuett, Cox
News Service) MOVED.

   YOUNG-COLUMN _ Drivers hitting 85 mph on Interstate 35 remind us
of a song at 45 (rpm). (Young, Waco Tribune-Herald) MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   HOMEDEPOT-WEB _ At long last, Home Depot unveils its e-commerce
site. The site is being tested in Las Vegas and is set to roll out
to a few other markets this year. Reporters will be able to access
the site on Tuesday. We'll recap the company's methodical journey
to the Web and why it took so long to make it there. (Bond, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   DELL _AUSTIN, Texas _ Dell is rolling out some new storage
products, trying to further expand their presence in a burgeoning
and lucrative market. Dell takes on the entry-level market, hoping
to replicate its success in desktops, workstations and servers with
volume, volume, volume. (Peltz, Austin American-Statesman)

   PUBLISHING _Peter Bowerman is a self-published author who
marketed and published his book ``virtually,'' that is with little
or no face-to-face interaction, all electronically. We'll learn how
technology is changing the book publishing business. (Mallory,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTO

   MONEYTALK _ ATLANTA _ Remember those times you noticed a stock
leaping in value and wished you had invested in it? Then you found
out, two days later, that a privileged few already knew a secret?
This month the Securities and Exchange Commission acted to curtail
such infuriating surprises. The SEC's new fair-disclosure rule
requires that publicly held companies spread the news to little-guy
investors at the same time they tell market professionals or major
stockholders. (Ezell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   GAPOWER-RACISM _ Georgia Power Co. is expected to detail actions
that have been taken to deal with the racially hostile workplace
enviroenment detailed in a discrimination case brought by seven
African-American employees. Attorneys for the employees, meanwhile,
allege that top utility officials, thepresident included, have been
intimidating potential members of a class action lawsuit and ask a
federal judge to tell them to stop. (Quinn, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   LIFESTYLE

   ALASKA-TRAVEL _ What happens when a person who hates the thought
of a shipboard vacation goes on an Alaska cruise? He loves it. WITH
ART. (Schultz, Palm Beach Post)

   WINE-COLUMN _ It makes no sense. Logic tells us that an
identical liquid sitting in two different containers is going to
taste and smell _ well, identical. No brainer. Then along comes
some smartypants to prove us wrong, to turn logic on its head, to
flout the laws of physics. What next? The sun rising in the west?
Maybe. But it's true. I was there. So were others. It was no mass
hallucination. (Fisher, Dayton Daily News) WITH PHOTOS

   Eds. Mark Fisher wine column MOVED.

   CRUMBS _ Kitty Crider food column. (Crider, Dayton Daily News)

   PSYCHOLOGY-LECRONE _ PSYCHOLOGY-LECRONE _ Last week's column
noted some of the reasons for stress in schoolteachers including
work overload, low pay, lack of control over results and lack of
positive feedback. In today's column I would like to discuss things
that can be done to help these educators. (LeCrone, Waco
Tribune-Herald) MOVED. ENTERTAINMENTNEWT-TV _ A preview/review of
the PBS special on the Fall of Newt Gingrich, a 90-minute special
narrated by Blair Brown that tracks Newt's exploits from the '98
elections through his retirement. (Jubera, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   Also moving in political category (p).

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   ARTHRITIS _ ``People like you shouldn't have children.'' The
doctor 's words, spoken 25 years ago, still make Leona Malone
teary-eyed. She has rheumatoid arthritis, one of nearly 100 types
of arthritis that can cripple and cause pain. But today, she also
has a 24-year-old daughter, a seat on an FDA advisory committee on
arthritis, and an award from the Arthritis Foundation for her
activism. She was 23 when she was diagnosed. Toi Leon, a beautiful
7-year-old who would outshine Jon Benet Ramsey in any beauty
pageant, has had this form of arthritis since she was 2. But she's
taking tap and jazz lessons and has zoomed from a Headstart program
for children behind in their learning to gifted classes. A look at
a disease that affects nearly one in six Americans in some form and
is the leading cause of disability. It's not just a disease of old
people. With photos. with graphic supporting story. (Susman, Palm
Beach Post) MOVED.

   SPORTS

   BASEBALL

   BBN-JORDAN _ Folllowing up on Brian Jordan shoulder injury. Hurt
while making a catch Monday night. (Rogers, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FOOTBALL

   FBN-DILLON _ Corey Dillon talked to reporters today about the
assault charge pending against him in Washington State. Dillon says
it was an accident but declines to tell reporters what happened.
His wife has filed for a protective order against him. He doesn't
intend to let what is hanging over him to cloud the team or his
play on the field. We'll touch base with Bengals management to find
out if they plan to fine him for missing practice on Monday and
lying about why he wasn't there. (Dayton Daily News)

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor Todd C. Duncan, 404-526-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.
